data.title: Women At War: The Forgotten Story Of Kosovo’s Female Liberators.
data.meta_description: In 1998, the last European war of the 20th century erupted in the breakaway Yugoslav province of Kosovo. A decade of repression by Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic pushed the province’s ethnic…
data.text:
In 1998, the last European war of the 20th century erupted in the breakaway Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

A decade of repression by Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic pushed the province’s ethnic Albanian population to revolution— and their ranks included hundreds of women.

From March 1998 to June 1999, hundreds of Albanian women took to the plains and hills of Kosovo to fight their Serbian oppressors. Their exact numbers may be unknown, but the story of Europe’s newest nation cannot be told without them.

The Setting

Under the Communist dictatorship of Josip Broz Tito, the Yugoslav province of Kosovo enjoyed limited autonomy (1). The province’s 90% Albanian majority held public sector jobs and even taught Albanian in schools (Yugoslavia being a mostly Serbo-Croatian speaking federation).

After Tito passed in 1980, Serbian nationalists filled the void, and relations soured. The nullification of Kosovar autonomy in…
